Award.AwardTitle: CPA-CSA: On-Chip Interconnection Networks for Scalable Integrated Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The successive innovations in semiconductor manufacturing over the<br/>last 35 years of Moore's law have turned what used to be a room-sized<br/>computer system into a single chip composed of billions of<br/>transistors. These levels of integration have forced a change toward<br/>parallelism in computer system design, including both single-chip<br/>multiprocessors and systems-on-a-chip. Today, these chips have a few<br/>tens of individual processors but future scaling will make hundreds or<br/>thousands available on a chip. Critical to the success of such systems<br/>is the hardware network that enables the processors on the chip to<br/>communicate with one another. Today's chips typically employ simple<br/>networks-on-chip (NOCs) such as bus, ring, or small grid. Future<br/>systems with numerous processors will need scalable and innovative<br/>NOCs to provide high communication bandwidth, low latency, and low<br/>power consumption.<br/><br/>This project seeks to develop scalable NOCs that are well suited to<br/>switch and wire capabilities in emerging chip fabrication<br/>technologies. In particular, the project would investigate new NOC<br/>topologies that exploit the enormous number of on-chip wires while <br/>reducing the number of hops to travel from a source to a destination. A<br/>second challenge is avoiding congestion in the network, much like<br/>avoiding automobile traffic congestion at rush hour. The investigation<br/>will develop new methods of monitoring the status of the routers and<br/>links in the network so that network messages can route themselves<br/>around network hotspots, improving network latency and bandwidth for<br/>all traffic. An important outcome of this research would be a public<br/>repository of network traces for different types of on-chip network traffic that will help improve the experimental methods of all NOC researchers.
